Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Isotopologue Synthesis and Use for Elucidating Important Chemical Mechanisms of Organic Condensation Reactions in Atmospheric Particles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Chemistry Division supports Professor Scot Martin of Harvard University and Professor Regan Thomson of Northwestern University. Their collaborative research addresses the complex roles played in the atmosphere by volatile organic molecules that are derived from plants. These molecules exchange between gases and particles in the atmosphere in ways that are poorly understood. Atmospheric particles, also known as aerosols, affect many important atmospheric processes, such as cloud formation, and the Earth's climate. The research team utilizes synthetic organic chemistry to make molecules thought to exist in the atmosphere and uses them in experiments designed to simulate atmospheric conditions. The outcome of this research may be an improved understanding of atmospheric processes, which allows for more accurate modelling of the weather and climate system. The research provides opportunities for students at both institutions as well as peer-to-peer learning. Through the "Faces of Science" YouTube series the researchers communicate science and personal stories to the general public, engaging diverse audiences.

This collaboration combines expertise in synthetic organic chemistry with expertise in atmospheric science. The team is advancing the understanding of the complex chemical processes in the particle phase of secondary organic aerosol particles. The synthesis enables access to a suite of complex, non-commercially available, yet highly atmospherically-relevant molecules with isotopic labeling. In particular, pinene isotopologue probes enable detailed studies of volatile biogenic terpenes. The aerosol experiments provide detailed mechanistic information regarding the formation and growth of atmospheric organic particles, as derived by use of the isotopologue probe species under varying conditions. Competing hypotheses of the prevailing chemical mechanisms are being tested and thus elucidate mechanistic aspects of oxidation/accretion pathways and particle formation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) constitute the subset of organic species with a vapor pressure above 0.01 kPa. These species are ubiquitous in the atmosphere. Emitted from both biogenic and anthropogenic sources, VOCs play a central role in atmosphere chemistry by influencing ecosystem functioning, pollutant formation, climatic processes, and human health.

For intellectual merit, this project studied the interactions between VOC compounds and atmospheric particles, focusing on particle physicochemical properties and the possible kinetic inhibition caused by high particle viscosity (Figure 1). Uptake of VOCs can in turn affect particle physicochemical properties, such as the plasticizing effect of RH-dependent water uptake. Thus, a complex feedback loop forms, and it remains incompletely understood (Figure 2). Main results are four-fold, as follows: (1) Procedures for the synthesis and study of not previously synthesized atmospherically-important compounds were developed (Figure 3). (2) The results established a method to measure reactive uptake of alpha-pinene photooxidation products to organosulfate particles. This uptake was tracked as a function of nitric oxide concentration during the photooxidation. Relative humidity was also established as an important influencer variable. (3) Analysis of the reactive uptake data related to particle hygroscopicity elucidated important qualitative and quantitative processes about the organosulfate particle physicochemical properties. (4) Machine learning established relationships between molecular structure and function and how these new relationships can be applied to the interpretation of laboratory data.

For broader impacts, this criterion encompasses the potential to benefit society and contribute to the achievement of specific, desired societal outcomes. In this context, the project contributed in three distinct aspects. Firstly, the research revealed important insights into the role that chemistry plays in the Earth’s climate system. These finding improve our ability to model the complexities of climate change to minimize its potential impacts on society. Secondly, through the development of collaborations between synthetic chemists and atmospheric scientists the research activities serve as a blueprint for how synergistic research can be conducted at the interface of scientific disciplines that rarely interact. Lastly, through the support of a Faces of Science seminar series awareness was raised in community to the roles that scientist backgrounds and identities play in their work.
